awd_titl_txt: Developing STEM Achievement and Motivation: The Role of Spatial Skills and Parent-Child Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
STEM learning is crucial for a well-prepared workforce, yet many students do not reach their potential in STEM. The roots of these individual differences can be traced back to school entry. Spatial skills - mentally representing and manipulating spatial information - strongly predict STEM achievement, course-taking, and careers. By 1st grade, children vary widely in spatial skills, pointing to the home environment's crucial role. The proposed research, led by a team of researchers at Temple University, will investigate the impact of parent-child interactions on spatial skills among 1st and 2nd graders. Importantly, not only skill but motivation- perceived competence, enjoyment of challenges, and low anxiety - impacts children's STEM trajectories. Unfortunately research on parents' support for children's STEM skills and motivation has proceeded in parallel, despite evidence that they reinforce one another. Prior research is also limited by short-term outcomes, parent self-report measures, or non-causal designs. The proposed studies will use longitudinal and experimental methods to 1carry out the following.  1) Identify specific aspects of parent-child interactions that predict children's spatial skills and STEM learning and motivation. 2) Establish causal relations between parents' cognitive support and children's spatial skills and motivation. 3) Establish causal relations between parents' motivational support and children's spatial skills and motivation. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning. 

This project will empirically test an integrated model of parents' cognitive and motivational support for children's spatial skills and STEM achievement. Study 1 will use video data from the NICHD Study of Early Child Care and Youth Development to test whether directly-observed parenting behaviors (cognitive and motivational support) during spatial activities in 1st grade predict children's STEM achievement and motivation through age 18. Studies 2a and 2b will test causal effects of parents' cognitive support on children's spatial and math skills and motivation via experimental parent-led spatial book-reading and spatial activity interventions. Study 3 will test the impact of increasing parents' motivational support on children's spatial and math skills and motivation. Investigating these factors in a single conceptual framework is crucial to understand whether they have additive, or possibly multiplicative, effects on children's development. For example, a parent who provides high motivational support may be more attuned to their child's level of skill, and therefore provide higher-quality cognitive support. Further, receiving both cognitive and motivational support may be especially impactful. Together, these studies will not only directly test the integrated theory of parents' cognitive and motivational support, but will have the added benefit of setting the foundation for larger parent-directed interventions aimed at improving all children's spatial skills and STEM achievement and motivation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The major goals of the project were to identify specific aspects of parent-child interactions that predict children’s spatial skills and STEM achievement and motivation, and to establish causal relations between parents’ cognitive support and children’s spatial skills and motivation. We accomplished these goals through three interrelated lines of research.

First, we established that spatial skills in 4th grade predicted students’ entry into a STEM college major many years later. Further, children with higher spatial skills in childhood were more likely to believe they were good at math, and this belief in turn predicted entering a STEM major. This provides the most long-term evidence to date of the relation of early spatial skills to students’ eventual pursuit of STEM fields and bolsters the evidence for the importance of the early development of spatial skills and math motivation.

Second, we investigated parents’ use of spatial language, praise, and talk about difficulty (i.e., how “easy” or “hard” tasks are) with young children, as well as students’ responses to these types of motivational talk. Based on detailed observations of parents and children interacting with different activities, we found that parents’ praise and spatial language with 6- and 7-year-olds varied by activity but not child sex, such that spatial activities elicited more praise and more spatial language than other activities, for both boys and girls. We also found that most families discussed difficulty (i.e., whether activities were “easy” or “hard”) and that talk about difficulty was more common during some activities than others (e.g., more frequent in a block construction task than a card game). Building on these observational findings, we conducted randomized experiments to examine how students react to praise and difficulty language. For example, in one study, we examined how 7- and 8-year-olds responded to praise and “easy” feedback while completing a spatial task. We found that process praise (“You must have worked hard on that puzzle”) and process-easy feedback (“It must have been easy to rotate and fit those pieces together”) had positive impacts on persistence and strategy generation after failure, supporting the importance of process-focused language for improving children’s motivation.

Third, we conducted a series of short-term randomized interventions, using pretest-intervention-posttest designs, to robustly examine how specific experiences impact children’s spatial skills. In one study, we examined whether boosting the frequency of spatial activities at home would increase children’s spatial skills. We randomly assigned families of 4- and 5-year-old children to receive a month-long spatial activity intervention or an active control condition involving narrative activities. Parents received physical materials (e.g., blocks and puzzles; wordless picture books) and tips on how to interact with the activities. Unexpectedly, the spatial intervention did not improve children's spatial skills. These findings, though unexpected, suggest that future research should consider not just the frequency of activities, but how families use those activities and whether children are actively involved.

We found more promising effects of a different type of spatial activity – reading picture books – on preschoolers’ mental rotation skills. We designed the books to practice mental rotation using child-friendly scenes, and experimenters incorporated rotation gestures while reading the books. Four- and 5-year-old children who read mental rotation books with an experimenter over two weeks improved in mental rotation skills (versus an active control condition). We argue that book-reading may be a promising avenue for improving mental rotation skills in early childhood.

Finally, we tested the impact of watching a brief (4-minute) mental rotation video on 2nd- and 3rd-graders spatial and mathematical performance. Replicating prior work, we found that this brief spatial training led to higher mental rotation performance and better arithmetic accuracy compared to an active control group. Importantly, spatial training reduced the frequency of non-spatial counting strategies (which are relatively basic strategies at this age) during the arithmetic task. This supports the theory that spatial skills may benefit mathematics learning by increasing the usage and efficiency of spatial problem-solving strategies.

Taken together, these studies establish the importance of spatial skills and motivation for later STEM success, identify training techniques that can improve spatial skills; and shed light on why spatial skills relate to math achievement in childhood.

Broader Impacts. This project established the importance of childhood spatial skills for STEM achievement and identified specific experiences that can increase young children’s spatial skills and motivation in STEM. This foundational research contributes to a strong theoretical and empirical basis for the future development of home- and school-based interventions to increase STEM interest, motivation, and achievement for all students. Further, this project provided training opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students, post-BA research assistants, and postdoctoral researchers, contributing to the future workforce of researchers in the science of learning.
